Q1. In the statement 

Odd 13

is Odd a type? What is the correct terminology?

Q2. In the statement 

Odd (13: ℤ)

Is ℤ a type also?

1. No, Odd is a function that returns a Prop, which might be called a "predicate". Odd (13 : ℤ) is a Prop. It's mostly ok to say that Odd (13 : ℤ) is a "type" and Odd is a "family of types", but you can't say it is a Type or "family of Types".
  2. Yes, ℤ : Type, which you can check with #check ℤ

Are you using "type" informally, and Type as something built into Lean?

I need to explore this more as I was surprised by your answer.

So 13 is not of type Odd. If I accept this, and go with Odd 13 is a predicate, meaning it is true or false, then Odd must be a property of 13.

Is "property" correct terminology?

So Odd and Even are properties that are defined in Mathlib, and can be true or false when applied to a number.

... just thinking out loud.

rzeta0 said:

Are you using "type" informally, and Type as something built into Lean?

Yes, arguably the Lean spelling of "type" as in "type theory" is Sort u, which generalizes over Type and Prop

So 24 hours later with some thinking about this .. I think I've come to the following understanding:

  • 13 has a type, and that is natural number.
  • Odd is definition. Objects conform to that definition or not. If they do, then the statement Odd n is true, else false.
  • It just so happens the Odd is implemented as a function with an input and output. Other definitions which result in true/false don't have to be a function?

Is this correct? Or at least not wrong?

You are inventing new words for "predicate" and for Prop (i.e. proposition) it sounds like. So it's hard to say whether it's correct or not -- if the mental model helps you, great -- Otherwise what you're calling definition is what Eric suggested "predicate" for, and what you're calling "thing which is true or false" is more or less what Lean calls Prop (though it is not really precisely "true or false" but rather "thing which has a proof if it's true and which will not if it's not true").

"Is equal to 37 or equal to 73" is I believe what you in your terminology would call "a definition which is implemented as a function which takes 2 inputs". You give me a number and I prove if it's either 37 or 73 (and then it's true) or else I cannot in which case it's false.

Actually I guess here "two numbers where the first number is 37 times the second number" is the example for a Prop-valued function of 2 arguments, you give me 2 numbers a and b and I should prove a = 37 * b for the "definition" to be true.

"There are an infinite number of primes" is I believe a "definition" which takes 0 arguments. Again though there's standard terminology for this in Lean, so once you get the concepts I think it's better if you do finally try to accept the terminology that's used for it.

Julian, I understand I think your recommendation to get used to the Lean documentation. Sadly it doesn't seem to match my intuition for what the concepts actually are.

Anyway, here is an example of the friction caused by the terminology.

To prove something is Odd, in plain paper maths we need to show it conforms to the definition of Odd. That is, Odd is a definition.

If we say Odd is a function, then the idea of checking to see if 13 conforms to a function, doesn't make immediate sense to most people coming from a non-Lean maths background, I would suggest.

(but I don't even have an undergrad degree in maths so tell me I'm wrong).

sin(z) is a function. What conforms to this function?

Prime is a definition. 13 conforms, but 12 doesn't.

sin(z) is a function. What conforms to this function?

Prime is a definition. 13 conforms, but 12 doesn't.

Both sin and Prime are both definitions and functions. The difference is that sin returns a real number, whereas Prime returns a proposition.

A quick note on notation: Lean uses functional-programming style notation for function calls. So instead of f(x), we write f x, and instead of f(sin(x)) we write f (sin x). This is done so that function calls work better with currying.

So sin 0 is a real number, which is 0. And Prime 13 is a proposition, which is (equivalent to) True. Also, Prime 12 is a valid proposition, which is (equivalent to) False.

One way to think about it is the following:

A proposition is a sentence that makes a claim that is either true or false. For example, “The dog is green” is a proposition whereas “Green” is not a proposition. We can prove whether or not propositions are true.

Similarly, we can prove whether or not the proposition “The number x is odd” is true but we cannot prove anything about “Odd” because it’s not a proposition (it’s not a sentence making a claim).

You can think of Odd as a function that when given a number x it returns the proposition “The number x is odd.”

So we cannot prove Odd because it is not a proposition, but we can prove Odd 13 because that is a proposition.

Or maybe a good way to see Odd is as an incomplete sentence: "is an odd number". You cannot prove "is an odd number"; you need a number to serve as the subject of the sentence: Odd is "something" that will give you a full true-or-false sentence if you give it a number.

And that's what a function is: "something" that will give you a thing of a given type (a sentence, a real number) if you give it a thing of the appropriate type (an integer, a real number). (There are other constraints, of course, like it will give you the same "thing" if you try it multiple times with the same "thing")

• So Odd is a function, which happens to be a useful definition.
  • And because it is a definition, the output is true/false (predicate).

That's correct?

• Yes
  • No, not all functions are true/false-valued. Eg sin is a function whose value is a real number
"predicate" usually means "a function of one argument that returns Prop (aka true/false)"
And "relation" is "a function of two arguments that returns Prop"

Yaël Dillies said:

  • Yes
  • No, not all functions are true/false-valued. Eg sin is a function whose value is a real number

Agreed, not all functions are true / false. But if a function is a definition, then the application to its parameters (one or more) results in true/false.

Is that right?
No. See the extensive discussion of the sine function above.

Definitions can have any type. They can be natural numbers like def thirtySeven := 37, functions from natural numbers to natural numbers like factorial, functions from reals to reals like sin, functions from natural numbers to propositions (aka predicates) like Odd. Not all functions are definitions; a definition is something that can expand to something in terms of lower level primitives and other definitions. An example of a function that is not a definition is Nat.succ, which is a function from natural numbers to natural numbers which is axiomatically postulated as part of the inductive type Nat.
Another common case where functions exist that aren't definitions is when you take a function as an argument, such as the f argument to Function.Injective

rzeta0 said:

Agreed, not all functions are true / false. But if a function is a definition, then the application to its parameters (one or more) results in true/false.

What you are describing here (a function which returns a proposition) is what we would call a predicate or relation. (The terms are used mostly interchangeably, but relations generally take more than one argument.)

So what I've learned from this thread is that my original question should have asked about the difference between a function and a definition.

  • not all functions are definitions, eg Nat.succ
  • all definitions are functions

Is the second point correct? If yes, that will help clarify things in my mind.
The second point is correct only if you consider "constants" like def two : Nat := 2 as zero-argument functions.

To summarize the terminology:

  • A type in Lean is an element of Sort n for some universe level n. So for example, Nat, Bool, and Type itself are types. By the Curry-Howard correspondence (aka propositions as types paradigm), propositions like "2 + 2 = 4" and "2 + 2 = 5" are types as well.
  • A function is an element of the type A -> B for some types A and B. (Technically many people would also consider dependent functions to be functions).
  • A proposition is an element of the type Prop (which is the same as Sort 0). These represent statements that can be true or false.
  • A predicate (also called a property) is an element of type A -> Prop for some type A. All predicates are functions, but none are types.
  • An explicitly-defined term is a variable that the user created with the def ... command. So this includes sin and Nat, but not Nat.succ nor Sort n.
  • A definition is not really a standardized term, so we don't use the term that often. Most people use it to refer to an actual "def ..." statement. Some people think definition = predicate, as you did at the start of the thread, and some think of definition = explicitly-defined term, as you did in your last message.

As examples:

  • 2 + 2 = 5 - a proposition and a type, but not a function or predicate.
  • sin - a function and explicitly-defined term, but not a type, proposition or a predicate.
  • Odd - a function, predicate, and explicitly-defined term, but not a type or proposition.
  • Odd 13, a proposition and a type, but not a function or predicate.
  • Nat.succ, a function, but not a proposition, predicate, type, or explicitly-defined term

Note that all propositions are also types (because of the Curry-Howard correspondence), and all predicates are also functions.

Niels Voss said:

  • A definition is not really a standardized term, so we don't use the term that often. Most people use it to refer to an actual "def ..." statement. Some people think definition = predicate, as you did at the start of the thread, and some think of definition = explicitly-defined term, as you did in your last message.

This is the only bullet I would disagree with. With my logician hat on "definition" very much is a standard term, and it means more or less what you called "explicitly-defined term", although it's less about whether you used the def command specifically as whether it is thought of as an abbreviation for something else and it can be unfolded to that.

it's less about whether you used the def command specifically as whether it is thought of as an abbreviation for something else and it can be unfolded to that.

So Int, Nat.succ, Classical.choice, and Nat -> Nat, are not considered definitions because they don't unfold to anything?

Right. (With the small caveat that sometimes things like Int are informally called definitions because they are another kind of conservative extension of the system, although to be perfectly rigorous about that it's not just Int but the whole package including Int.ofNat, Int.negSucc and Int.rec. But it doesn't meet the strict criterion for being a definition that I gave.)

would it be helpful for Lean to designate some objects as axiomatic?

to make it clear to readers/writers of code that something is axiomatic, and others are derived eg definitions.

currently you either know or you don't.

(and it possibly also then allows systems to be constructed from user-defined axioms)
There is an axiom command

rzeta0 said:

currently you either know or you don't.

Is this not something that's answered by "go to definition" in the editor?

@Kyle Miller

As you say, go to definition will take you to the definition, and you can keep following "go to definition".

But nothing in the code highlights that an object is axiomatic.

I just tried to go back from 13 to inductive Nat and reading the code doesn't tell me it is axiomatic.

I guess "go to definition" on Nat takes me to itself, which might be a clue, but this seems not ideal.

(caveat - I'm out of my depth with this question, I'm just curious)

What exactly is the difference between "axiomatic" and "non-axiomatic"?
The existence of inductive types is posited by an axiom of type theory. Nat is a particular inductive type, with an explicit definition: namely, it has the two constructors zero : Natand succ : Nat -> Nat.
So is Nat axiomatic because its definition doesn't involve the keyword def in the Lean syntax? Or is it non-axiomatic because its existence just follows from the axioms (like anything else), but is not itself an axiom?

If you use #print, it will reliably tell you if something is a definition or not.

  • If it says axiom, inductive, structure, class, constructor, recursor, or Quotient primitive then it's not a definition, it doesn't unfold to anything.
  • If it says def then it's a definition.
  • If it says opaque, then it's borderline: it's not a definition by my strict definition of the term (it doesn't unfold), but it is a conservative extension.
  • If it says theorem it's also borderline, because it's also like opaque except that it is actually defeq to its body anyway because it's a proof
